articles.headline: Senate Hearing Draws Out a Rift in U.S. Policy on Syria
articles.snippet: Deep divisions in the Obama administration over rising violence in Syria spilled into public view for the first time in a blunt exchange between Senator John McCain of Arizona and the leaders of the Pentagon.
articles.abstract: Deep divisions in the Obama administration over rising violence in Syria spilled into public view for the first time in a blunt exchange between Senator John McCain of Arizona and the leaders of the Pentagon.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his first term, President Obama presided over an administration known for its lack of open dissension on critical foreign policy issues.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Mark Landler

articles.headline: U.S. Official Faults F.A.A. for Missing 787 Battery Risk
articles.snippet: As a transportation official said tests in 2007 failed to anticipate potential incidents, the Federal Aviation Administration approved flights of the Boeing jet to collect data.
articles.abstract: As a transportation official said tests in 2007 failed to anticipate potential incidents, the Federal Aviation Administration approved flights of the Boeing jet to collect data.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s top transportation safety official said on Thursday that the Federal Aviation Administration accepted test results from Boeing in 2007 that failed to properly assess the risks of smoke or fire from the batteries on Boeing’s new 787 jets.
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Restored Payroll Tax Pinches Those Who Earn the Least
articles.snippet: At street level, the pain from the expiration of a two-percentage-point break in Social Security taxes in 2011 and 2012 is evident.
articles.abstract: At street level, the pain from the expiration of a two-percentage-point break in Social Security taxes in 2011 and 2012 is evident.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jack Andrews and his wife no longer enjoy what they call date night, their once-a-month outing to the movies and a steak dinner at Logan’s Roadhouse in Augusta, Ga. In Harlem, Eddie Phillips’s life insurance payment will have to wait a few more weeks. And Jessica Price is buying cheaper food near her home in Orlando, Fla., even though she worries it may not be as healthy.

articles.headline: In Actions, S.&P. Risked Andersen’s Fate
articles.snippet: A federal suit paints Standard & Poor’s as willing to cut corners to keep its customers — much as the accounting firm did in the Enron scandal.
articles.abstract: A federal suit paints Standard & Poor’s as willing to cut corners to keep its customers — much as the accounting firm did in the Enron scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: They were the gatekeepers, with a clear conflict of interest — the people they were supposed to check up on were also the ones who hired and paid them. The need to protect their reputation was supposed to assure that the conflict would not lead to bad behavior.

articles.headline: In Italy, a Factory Too Fragile for Its Time
articles.snippet: For nearly 300 years, the Richard Ginori factory produced singular, handcrafted and elegant porcelain tableware, but the factory was declared bankrupt in January.
articles.abstract: For nearly 300 years, the Richard Ginori factory produced singular, handcrafted and elegant porcelain tableware, but the factory was declared bankrupt in January.
articles.lead_paragraph: SESTO FIORENTINO, Italy — For nearly 300 years, the Richard Ginori factory here produced singular, handcrafted and elegantly decorated porcelain tableware. Its pieces have graced museums and the tables of the world’s wealthy and aspiring middle class. In March, the Pitti Palace, in Florence, will exhibit Ginori porcelain from the Napoleonic occupation of Tuscany.

articles.headline: Business and Labor Unite to Try to Alter Immigration Laws
articles.snippet: Two oft-feuding groups, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Chamber of Commerce, have formed an alliance to find a way for immigrants illegally in the United States to gain citizenship.
articles.abstract: Two oft-feuding groups, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Chamber of Commerce, have formed an alliance to find a way for immigrants illegally in the United States to gain citizenship.
articles.lead_paragraph: After decades of friction over immigration, the nation’s labor unions and the leading business association, the Chamber of Commerce, have formed an unusual alliance that is pushing hard to revamp American immigration laws.

articles.headline: H.P. Directs Its Suppliers in China to Limit Student Labor
articles.snippet: New rules from Hewlett-Packard, one of the world’s largest makers of computers and other tech products, reflect a major shift in how electronics companies view Chinese labor practices.
articles.abstract: New rules from Hewlett-Packard, one of the world’s largest makers of computers and other tech products, reflect a major shift in how electronics companies view Chinese labor practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Hewlett-Packard, one of the world’s largest makers of computers and other electronics, is imposing new limits on the employment of students and temporary agency workers at factories across China. The move, following recent efforts by Apple to increase scrutiny of student workers, reflects a significant shift in how electronics companies view problematic labor practices in China.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and David Barboza

articles.headline: European Leaders Agree, Finally, to a Lower Budget
articles.snippet: The slimmer budget maintains Europe’s climate of austerity, but the colossal effort that was required to reach a deal raises serious questions about the limits of European integration.
articles.abstract: The slimmer budget maintains Europe’s climate of austerity, but the colossal effort that was required to reach a deal raises serious questions about the limits of European integration.
articles.byline: By James Kanter and Andrew Higgins
